Heres an email from David: In 1967, I was an impressionably young white student at San Francisco State.
I had the opportunity to hear Eldridge Cleaver give several speeches, always ending with the chant - power to the people.
I, along with many others, was energized and imbued with a sense of our power and ability to make change in the face of overwhelming institutional entrenchment.
Could your guest comment on this powerful phrase, chant, war song, for the movement - power to the people.
Power to the people comes out of the black consciousness, black power, black nationalist movement that was after that followed as an activist period after the civil rights movement.
And what you have there is a movement against racism, which is a civil rights movement.
And then as we move forward, we begin to look at what were we in the culture.
And there was a period where we actually begin to study and re-understand who we were as a people.
And so the whole black consciousness, black power, black studies movement would have had on the most activist edge people in the street going power to the people.
And this is where you get your black mayors in cities.
Mm-hmm.
You get urban areas.
You also get what we call urban rebellions, so thats that power to the people it's a very activist protracted movement.
And there was a spectrum from the Black Panthers to black mayors.
This is WEEKEND EDITION from NPR News.
I'm Rachel Martin.
And that music means it's time to talk about the national budget deficit - I kid, I kid - it's time for the puzzle.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
To black studies and African-American studies departments in colleges.
And the colleges were not just the white colleges.
We had to struggle with the black colleges to teach African-American culture and history.
So the struggle was throughout the system.
And power to the people is one of the aggressive edges, expressions of that period.
I had then a group called the Harambee Singers.
Harambee is Swahili, meaning lets pull together.
So I was right there.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Bernice Johnson Reagon with us here in Studio 3A.
We thank her for her time today, along with her daughter, Toshi Reagon, who was kind enough to be with us as well.
Thanks as well to Sierra Reaux-McNeil, a senior at Duke Ellington's High School of the Arts here in Washington, D.C., who attended the workshop Music that Inspired the Movement at the White House.
Thanks very much for coming in.
Thank you.
We want to end with this email that we got from Carol: I'd like to contribute my memory about listening to the civil rights freedom movement song affected me.
I was visiting the capital of the Soviet Union, Moscow, in 1975.
We visited a high school and students stood in a large circle with us, took hands and sang ""We Shall Overcome,"" with which we joined.
I was so moved that this group of Russian high school students knew our American history and songs of freedom.
This, ""We Shall Overcome,"" recorded in a mass meeting in Hattiesburg, Mississippi in 1964.
You're listening to TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
(Soundbite of song, ""We Shall Overcome"")
(Singing) ...we shall overcome some day, oh, deep in my heart I do believe, we shall overcome some day...
Okay, from sinking news standards to the sinking housing market.
Some people who bought high during the housing boom are having a really tough time making their mortgage payments across the country.
Foreclosures jumped some 42 percent last year.
San Francisco, home to expensive houses, is particularly hard hit.
Nancy Mullane reports from member station KALW.
Michelle Full(ph) and Ryan Takamoto(ph) are standing outside a coffee shop chatting with their real estate agent.
After months of traipsing through open houses, this may be the day they find their dream property.
Full says that would mean a house they can afford.
The really nice houses are like 1.5, $2 million.
And you think, okay, could I really do this?
It's very tempting, but you know, in the end it's still a lot of money.
Buying more than the budget allows in a city like San Francisco can be tempting.
The problem is, people all over the country have been pushing those limits.
Eddie O'Sullivan is Full and Takamoto's real estate agent.
He says he tries to show his clients only the properties he knows they can afford.
But he says lenders have been willing to offer buyers more money, and that can mean trouble down the road.
Mr.

EDDIE O'SULLIVAN (Real Estate Agent): The bank will always give them that cushion where they tell them, look, this is, you know, for what you're willing to spend; this is what you can afford; but we'll lend you up to this amount.
After all, banks and other lenders make money on the interest paid on a mortgage.
But Sullivan says the problem is the exotic home loans lenders have been offering homebuyers with less than stellar credit.
The favorable terms of zero interest, adjustable, or so-called NegAm loans change over time, usually after a couple of years, and can become very expensive.
Often times the homebuyer pays just a portion of the interests on the loan each month - kind of like a minimum payment on a credit card.
The rest is tacked on to the principal.
You end up in a situation when you're stuck in a loan.
If you're only able to make those minimal payments, then ending up in a loan that just gets bigger and bigger and bigger.
That's what happened to Patricia Barbera(ph).
She bought her dream home with an adjustable rate mortgage.
As the mortgage increased, she got caught up, unable to make the payments on time.
Barbera received one notice of default and then another.
Late payment fees were attached.
Then, she says, the lender began foreclosure proceedings.
I don't know whether it's like anything else, but it is pretty dramatic when you're in a situation where you may be losing your home; that's pretty scary.
Barbera fought back.
She hired an attorney and challenged some of the late fees and other charges the lender attached to the default debt.
So far, she's been able to keep her home, but she says it's not over.
I just go one day at a time and fight, and fight, and fight.
Often times, it's not in the bank's interest to foreclose on a home, and they maybe willing to renegotiate the loan.
For those homeowners who aren't able to make some kind of a deal, a foreclosure sale of their property can occur within three months of receiving a notice of default.
In San Francisco, foreclosure sales take place on the steps of city hall.
This is a trustee sale - opening bid of $389,845.
Over the next 45 minutes, a half dozen men standing in a drizzling rain place bids on a foreclosure property in the city.
All of the men carry cashiers checks in their hands.
The checks prove they can pay for the property if their bid wins.
Unidentified Man #2: 540,000 for the third and final time.
Are there any further bids?

Even though foreclosure rates across California jumped 145 percent in the fourth quarter of 2005, that's an increase over unnaturally low numbers of the past few years, when buyers were earning equity on their homes.
But according to Thomas Davidoff, an economist at U.C.
Berkeley, foreclosures will likely continue.
If things start to stumble along, you know, minor recession, minor recovery, I don't think we're going to see a big increase in house prices.
And so I think we'll see some more defaults.
I think that will happen over the next five years.
The rising tide of mortgage delinquency and foreclosure rates has gotten the attention of Congress.
Just yesterday, Senator Christopher Dodd, chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, said it may be time for federal regulators to intervene and crack down on irresponsible lending practices.
